questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida delivers a baby at 30 weeks of gestation. The newborn skin appears very thin and translucent. Which of the following layers of epidermis will be absent in this baby?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Stratum Corneum

 

Explanation:

A newborn delivered at 30 weeks of gestation is preterm, and the skin shows typical features such as:

  • Thin, translucent appearance

  • Increased permeability and fluid loss

  • Poor barrier protection

These are due to the immature development of the epidermis, specifically the stratum corneum.

Stratum Corneum is absent or poorly developed in infants <32–34 weeks.

  • Begins forming around 24–26 weeks, but by 30 weeks, it's still only a few thin layers.

  • Fully developed only by 34–37 weeks gestation.

  • Its absence leads to impaired barrier function, making the skin look shiny, red, and gelatinous.

  • Layers of epidermis (from superficial to deep):
    • Stratum corneum
    • Stratum lucidum
    • Stratum granulosum
    • Stratum spinosum
    • Stratum basale

 

Stratum Spinosum (Option A) is incorrect because this layer, responsible for structural integrity and desmosomal connections, is already present by 30 weeks, although still immature.

Stratum Granulosum (Option B) is incorrect because it is usually present by mid-second trimester; keratohyalin granules may be reduced, but the layer is not absent.

Stratum Basale (Option C) is incorrect because it is the first to form, appearing by 8–10 weeks of gestation, and serves as the basal proliferative layer.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic complaining of persistent dryness and itching on her hands and arms for several months which seem to worsen during the winter months. On examination, dry, scaly patches are observed on the dorsal aspects of her hands and arms. She denies any history of eczema or other skin conditions. What protein deficiency in the epidermis is most likely responsible for the observed skin manifestations in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Filaggrin:

  • Filaggrin helps in keratin filament aggregation in stratum corneum and is subsequently broken down into individual hygroscopic amino acids that form the basis of the natural moisturizing factor within corneocytes.
    • Filaggrin is formed from profilaggrin in the stratum corneum which is derived from keratohyalin granules of stratum granulosum.
    • Deficiency or dysfunction of filaggrin is associated with various skin conditions, including atopic dermatitis (eczema) and Ichthyosis vulgaris.

 

 

Keratin

Collagen

Elastin

Location

Epidermis

Dermis (predominant protein)

Dermis

Function

Protective barrier

Provide tensile strength and support to the skin.

Provides elasticity to the skin.

Defects

Formation of blisters in response to minor trauma or friction.

Impair the formation of new tissue and delay wound healing processes.

Accelerate the ageing process, resulting in sagging skin and increased susceptibility to wrinkling.

 

Keratin (Option A): Structural protein in the skin, nails, and hair. Provides mechanical strength, but not directly involved in moisture retention or barrier hydration. Keratin defects cause conditions like epidermolysis bullosa simplex or keratinopathies, not xerosis or winter dryness.

Collagen (Option C): A dermal protein (not epidermal). Provides tensile strength to the skin and connective tissue. Deficiencies or mutations cause connective tissue disorders like Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, not dry scaly skin.

Elastin(Option D): ​​​​​​​Another dermal protein, responsible for skin elasticity. Defects lead to loose, saggy skin (e.g., cutis laxa), not dry itchy patches. Not involved in the epidermal barrier function.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is responsible for lipid secretion and maintaining skin barrier function
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lamellar Granules:

  • Lamellar granules, also known as Odland bodies or Membrane-coating granules, are present in the stratum granulosum.
    • They are secreted into intercellular space to play a major role in barrier function by producing the lipid content in the epidermis and intercellular cohesion within the stratum corneum.
    • Dysfunction or abnormalities of Odland bodies lead to conditions disrupting the skin barrier such as Eczema and Icthyosis.

 

Eleidin Granules (Option A): Eleidin granules are specialized organelles found in stratum lucidum which is present only in palms and soles. They contribute to the keratinization, translucency, and barrier function.

Keratohyalin Granules (Option B): These granules are found primarily in the stratum granulosum and secrete a protein called profilaggrin, which transforms into filaggrin. This protein helps keratin filaments aggregate and maintains skin hydration and barrier.

Birbeck Granules (Option D): These granules are found in Langerhans cells in the stratum spinosum of the epidermis. On electron microscopy, they appear to be ‘tennis racquet‘- shaped.Birbeck granules facilitate antigen processing and presentation in Langerhans cells, aiding in immune response.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of thick, red plaques with silvery scales on his elbows, knees, and scalp for several months that have been worsening gradually. There is also pitting and discolouration of his fingernails and toenails. Which of the following pathological changes in the epidermis is associated with this condition?

choices.text: No change in the epidermal layer

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Decreased epidermal turnover time

  • Epidermal turnover or transit time or Keratinocyte transit time is the time taken by the keratinocytes to migrate from the basal layer to the surface of the skin as fully matured Keratinocytes.
    • Cells take 14 days to migrate from the Stratum Basale to the Stratum Corneum.
    • They stay at Stratum Corneum for another 14 days.
    • After which Cells exfoliate. It takes approximately 28 days.
    • The total duration may range between 52-75 days.
  • In psoriasis, the rate of cell proliferation in the basal layer of the epidermis increases significantly. This results in the rapid turnover and migration of epidermal cells towards the skin surface, which decreases epidermal transit time to 4 days.

 

Increased epidermal turnover time (Option A): The epidermal turnover is decreased in psoriasis due to the rapid proliferation of cells in the epidermis. This accelerated turnover contributes to the formation of characteristic plaques, erythema, and scaling in psoriatic lesions.

Increased thickness of granular layer (Option C): In psoriasis, the thickness of the granular layer in the skin is typically reduced or absent.

No change in the epidermal layer (Option D): In psoriasis, the epidermis undergoes several distinct changes that contribute to the disease's clinical manifestations.

questions.text: Which of the following cells is exclusively present in the stratum spinosum layer of epidermis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Langerhans cells

Explanation:

Langerhans cells are exclusively found in the Stratum spinosum layer of the epidermis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of multiple erosions and blisters on her hands, face, and forearms. She was diagnosed with bullous pemphigoid. Which of the following structures is most directly implicated in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hemidesmosomes:

  • Hemidesmosomes are specialized cell junctions that anchor epithelial cells to the basement membrane.
  • Dysfunction of hemidesmosomes can lead to blistering disorders, such as bullous pemphigoid, in which autoantibodies target hemidesmosome components, particularly BP180 (collagen XVII) and BP230, which are integral proteins anchoring epithelial cells to the basement membrane.

 

Desmosomes (Option A):

  • Desmosomes are cell junctions consisting of proteins called desmogleins and desmocollins. They form transmembrane links between adjacent cells and intracellular intermediate filaments, such as keratin.
  • Autoantibodies against both desmoglein 1 (Dsg1) and desmoglein 3 (Dsg3) will be seen in pemphigus vulgaris and only against desmoglein 1 (Dsg1) in pemphigus foliaceous.

Keratin 5 and 14 (Option C):

  • These are intermediate filament proteins primarily expressed in basal keratinocytes. They are essential for maintaining the structural integrity of the epidermis by providing mechanical strength and resilience to epithelial tissues.
  • Mutations in K5 and K14 result in weakened keratin filaments leading to a condition called Epidermolysis bullosa simplex (EBS).

Laminin (Option D):

  • Laminin 332 (also known as laminin-5) is a major laminin found in the basement membrane zone (BMZ). It promotes the migration of epithelial cells during tissue repair and wound healing processes.
  • Dysregulation of its expression or function is associated with Junctional epidermolysis bullosa.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with a history of frequent fractures with minimal trauma. Physical examination reveals blue sclerae, triangular face, and short stature. Radiographic findings show multiple fractures in various stages of healing, thinning of long bones, and wormian bones in the skull. Which of the following is the correct combination regarding the defective protein and its location in the skin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Collagen - Dermis

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario suggests Osteogenesis imperfecta, also known as brittle bone disease. This genetic disorder is characterized by defective collagen (Type I) synthesis.

The dermis is a connective tissue layer present between the epidermis and hypodermis and is mainly composed of collagen and some elastin.

It plays a major role in maintaining the structural integrity, elasticity, and functionality of the skin.

 

Collagen

It makes up 70% of connective tissue in the dermis

It makes up 2 - 4% of the dermis. (Option B)

Function

Responsible for the tensile strength.

Responsible for elasticity, allowing to stretch and recoil.

Other locations

Type I collagen is the most common type in the skin which is also present in bone, tendons, and ligaments.

Also present in the blood vessels, lungs, and ligaments contributing to their resilience and flexibility

The hypodermis is primarily composed of subcutaneous fat, which provides thermal insulation and helps regulate body temperature.(Option C)

Elastin—Dermis (Option D): This combination is true, but in the clinical scenario, the defective protein is collagen.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions will not show the presence of nuclei retained in the stratum corneum as a pathological finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lichen planus

Explanation:

  • Since epidermal turnover is not affected in lichenoid reactions, parakeratosis is not commonly seen in lichen planus. Instead, it is associated with hyperkeratosis, which is the thickening of the stratum corneum.
  • The stratum corneum is the topmost layer of the epidermis, where cells (keratinocytes/corneocytes) have lost the nuclei and cytoplasmic organelles.

Parakeratosis:

  • The retention of nuclei in the keratinocyte of the stratum corneum, known as Parakeratosis, is associated either with increased epidermal cell turnover or with inflammatory changes in the epidermis itself.
  • It is seen in psoriasis, sub-acute eczema, squamous cell carcinoma, and actinic keratoses.
  • Parakeratosis is physiological in oral mucosa and vaginal mucosa.

Both Parakeratosis and Hyperkeratosis are pathological findings that can be seen in the Stratum corneum.

Eczema (Option A): Parakeratosis is seen as a pathological finding in sub-acute eczematous reactions.

 

Psoriasis (Option B): In psoriasis, both parakeratosis and hyperkeratosis can be seen.

 

Bowen’s disease (Option D): Bowen’s disease is an in-situ squamous cell carcinoma of the epidermis. In this condition, nuclei retention (due to incomplete maturation of epidermal keratinocytes) in the stratum corneum can be seen as a pathological finding.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the dermatology clinic with a complaint of pruritic, erythematous patches on her arms and legs. A skin biopsy specimen was done and microscopic examination shows intercellular oedema between keratinocytes within the epidermis. Which of the following terms best describes the microscopic finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Spongiosis:

  • Explanation:
    • The condition given in the clinical scenario is Acute eczema.
    • Spongiosis, also known as Intercellular oedema, is the widening of intercellular spaces between keratinocytes caused by fluid accumulation.
    • It is the characteristic histopathological change seen in acute and subacute eczematous reactions.
    • It primarily occurs in the stratum spinosum layer of the epidermis and may extend to the stratum granulosum depending on the severity and extent of an inflammatory process.

 

Acantholysis (Option A): Acantholysis refers to the loss of intercellular connections between keratinocytes within the epidermis, leading to the formation of intraepidermal blisters or erosions. This phenomenon is characteristic of diseases such as pemphigus vulgaris and Pemphigus foliaceus

 

 

 

Basal cell degeneration (Option B): Degeneration of the basal cell layer is one of the characteristic changes seen in Lichen planus.

 

Acanthosis (Option C): Acanthosis refers to epidermal hyperplasia characterized by thickening of the stratum spinosum layer of the epidermis. It is often observed in conditions such as chronic eczemas.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with persistent red scaly patches on his scalp. On examination, erythematous plaques with adherent silver scales are noted on the scalp, particularly in the parietal and occipital regions. He was diagnosed with psoriasis. Which of the following histopathological changes is seen at the lower epidermis in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Elongation of rete ridges:

Explanation:

Rete ridges are extensions of the epidermis that project downward into the dermis, forming finger-like projections.

  • They play a crucial role in maintaining the skin's structural integrity and function by increasing the surface area of the dermal-epidermal junction and enhancing adhesion between the skin layers.
  • In psoriasis, regular elongation of rete ridges is seen
  • The part of the dermis that invaginates into the epidermis is the ‘papillary dermis’, which carries capillaries between the rete ridges (pinpoint bleeding spots in Auspitz sign are due to rupture of these dilated blood vessels).

 

Munro’s micro abscess (Option A): It is also seen in psoriasis but it is the collection of neutrophils at the level of stratum corneum.

Another collection of neutrophils at the level of stratum spinosum in psoriasis is the ‘Spongiform pustule of kogoj’.

Pautrier's microabscess (Option B): In Cutaneous T cell Lymphoma/ Mycosis fungoides, the atypical lymphocytes infiltrate the epidermis and form clusters within these layers, leading to the formation of Pautrier's microabscesses. 

 

Flattening of rete ridges (Option D): It is seen in conditions characterized by epidermis atrophy, such as lichen sclerosis and atrophic dermatitis.
